question: What is the average monthly rent in Lisbon?
answer: The average monthly rent for a private room in Lisbon is around €490. If you're looking for a studio apartment, the average cost would be around €1,056 per month. For larger apartments, you can expect to pay an average of €1,750 per month. However, prices can vary greatly depending on which neighborhood you choose to live in.

question: What steps should I take after arriving in Lisbon?
answer:
Welcome to Lisbon! I'm glad you've made it here. After arriving, there are a few important steps to help you settle in.

Firstly, as an international student, you'll need to register your residence with the local authorities. This is usually done at your local town hall or city council. Make sure to carry all necessary documents like your passport, visa, and proof of accommodation. You may also need to provide a European Health Insurance Card (EHIC). Don't worry if you don't have it right away; you can apply for it in your home country before leaving or once you arrive in Portugal.

Secondly, getting around Lisbon is convenient with its public transportation system. I recommend considering a monthly subscription with a Navegante card if you plan to travel frequently. This will save you money compared to individual tickets.

Lastly, don't forget to explore your new city! Lisbon offers a rich cultural experience and diverse food scene. Enjoy your journey in this vibrant European capital.

question: As a non-EU student, what are the requirements to study at NOVA IMS in Lisbon?
answer:
To study at NOVA IMS as a non-EU student, you'll need to meet a few key requirements. First, you must be admitted into one of our Master’s or Postgraduate programs. Once admitted, you can apply for a student visa. NOVA IMS will issue an admission document that you can use in your application process. This document will only be provided after the pre-registration fee has been paid.

It's important to note that you should contact the Portuguese Embassy or Consulate in your home country to get the most accurate and up-to-date information about the specific visa requirements and application process for your nationality. Also, keep in mind that processing times can vary greatly, so it's recommended to submit your complete application at least two months before your intended departure date.

If you need any further assistance or have other questions related to studying at NOVA IMS, living in Lisbon, or the Portuguese student visa process, feel free to ask!

A: NOVA IMS can issue a document that proves admission in the program, that will be sent to the student and the Embassy. The document will only be issued or provided after the payment of the pre-registration fee. Regardless of issuance the document, the student must contact the Portuguese Embassy or Consulate in their country to get more information.

question: What is the Portuguese Social Security Identification Number (NISS), and why do I need it?
answer: The Portuguese Social Security Identification Number, or NISS for short, is a unique identifier used by the Portuguese Social Security system to accurately identify individuals. It's like a personal ID number that allows you access to various rights and obligations within the social security system. So, when you move to Portugal as a student, you'll need to apply for your NISS to ensure you can access the services and benefits associated with it.

question: How can a foreign citizen obtain a NISS?
answer: A foreign citizen can obtain a National Insurance System number, or NISS, in Portugal by filling out the form available on the Social Security portal. They will need to attach the necessary documents as specified in the application process. However, if they have already requested the allocation of a NISS through the Social Security Portal and also apply for a NISS, NIF, and NNU allocation at one of the Customer Information Services, only one NISS will be allocated, even with two applications. If you're an international student coming to study at NOVA IMS, don't worry if you can't submit some documents right away, like a residence permit or proof of professional activity. You'll still be able to apply for your NISS using the forms and instructions provided on the Social Security portal. Your biggest living expense in Lisbon will certainly be the cost of your rent. The average cost of rent in Lisbon hit a peak during 2023, but has been decreasing ever since. question: As a higher education student, how can I obtain a residence permit in Portugal?
answer:
Absolutely, I'd be happy to help you navigate the process of obtaining a residence permit as a higher education student in Portugal. If you're coming from another European Union member state, and your stay is expected to last longer than 90 days, you would apply for a residence permit for higher education students with a visa exemption. This can be done upon arrival in Portugal.

If you're coming from a third country and already hold a Residence Visa for Higher Education Students, you'll need to apply for this residence permit as well if your stay is going to exceed 90 days. The process involves submitting your application along with the necessary documents at the Portuguese Immigration and Border Service (SEF).

It's important to note that holders of a residence permit for higher education students in Portugal, or those from EU member states with a similar permit, are authorized to stay in Portugal for more than 90 days within any 180-day period. If you need to extend your stay beyond this time, you can apply for a renewal of the residence permit.

I hope this information helps clarify the process. Let me know if you have any other questions!
